Expectation1: Communicate politely and professionally with customers
Situation1: The customer asks about the delivery status
Expectation2: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation2: A relaxed evening lies ahead with no other commitments.
Story: I had just finished my last delivery for the day and was looking forward to a quiet evening. As a Muslim, I cherish these rare moments when I can sit in peace, recite the Quran, and reflect on its meaning without any rush. I had planned everything: a cup of tea, my favorite surah, and the gentle hum of the evening outside my window. Just as I settled in, my phone buzzed. It was a customer from earlier, asking about the status of their delivery. As a delivery person, I’m expected to respond quickly and professionally, always polite and helpful, no matter the hour. But my heart was already in a different place, yearning for spiritual connection and tranquility. I stared at the phone, feeling the weight of both roles pressing on me—one demanding immediate attention and courteous communication, the other calling me to spiritual devotion and inner peace. The conflict twisted inside me, each expectation pulling me in a different direction, and I sat there, torn, unsure which part of myself to honor first.
